subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 20th March 2020: Largest weekly stock decline since ‘08 as global economy falls off a cliff edge
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: Senate proposes USD 1trln stimulus package; chunky Quadwiching; Fed ramps up FX swap lines; UK and US step up domestic restrictions; UK to pay wages for the first time ever.
  • COMING UP: Data: US Stimulus Package Negotiations; EZ Consumer Confidence (Flash) on Monday.

MARKET WRAP:

Stocks reversed earlier gains into losses, marking a weekly loss of 15% for the SPX, albeit the VIX has cooled somewhat from its all-time highs mid-week. Investors continue to demand lower prices as the US and global economy begins to fall off a cliff amid a wide-ranging shutdown. Fiscal and monetary stimulus has been let loose and continues to ramp up – Senate is proposing a USD 1trln stage 3 package for Monday and UK is to begin paying wages for the first time ever – in a markedly more steadfast fashion than had been seen in the 2008/09 crisis, as policymakers strive to be proactive rather than reactive. Ironically, after a week of multiple limit downs/ups hit, none were reached on Friday despite what desks noted as one of the largest ever OpEx (quad witching). Nonetheless, the week has been one for the history books, with BofA’s latest flow show printing largest-ever weekly outflows in IG and EM debt, MBS, municipal bonds and TIPs, with its 4th largest recorded inflow into cash ever – a theme that has driven the weak as investors have moved out of all assets into the US dollar; ramped up US dollar FX swap lines announced today helped cool the bid somewhat on Friday.

COVID-19:

US STIMULUS: US Senate Majority Leader McConnell introduced the Senate GOP stimulus plan, named the CARES Act and worth USD 1trln, which includes direct payments of USD 1,200 per person, relief for small businesses and workers, as well as fresh healthcare-related support. Furthermore, the coronavirus bill provides up to USD 208bln in collateralized loans and loan guarantees to US industries including USD 58bln for airlines, with bipartisan discussions to begin today. Democratic Senator Menendez said the bill would let the Fed buy municipal bonds of any maturity – a feature that would reduce strain on the Federal government. There were separate reports that US Governors are seeking at least USD 150bln in direct aid from the package. Meanwhile, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the tax filing deadline will be moved from April 15th to July 15th, a decision that will likely have to be substituted with further. Mnuchin said overnight that the plan is to get the bill passed and signed by President Trump on Monday; later said the USD 1trln bill is too small and wants more direct cash payments – the latter is a measure that has drawn scepticism among lawyers. President Trump himself said he is talking about much more than a USD 1,000 check for unemployed Americans in a press conference.

US TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS: All non-essential workforce members in New York must stay at home, Governor Cuomo announced, where only “essential” businesses can have commuting workers. California overnight reported a state-wide stay at home order. NIH’s Fauci said social distancing in the US should continue for a number of weeks. The US announced that it had agreed with Mexico to restrict non-essential travel across their border as of midnight, Friday, stressing that the restrictions do not apply to trade and commerce. President Trump noted that the US is not considering a national lock-down at this time, doesn't think it will ever be necessary.

UK STIMULUS: Chancellor Sunak announced a combination of measures on jobs and incomes, where, for the first time, the UK government will help to pay wages. Any employer will be eligible for grants covering wages of those who have been furloughed and kept on salary, which will cover 80% of the salary of retained workers of up to GBP 2,500 per month, backdated to March 1st, for at least three months, with no limit on funding available. Furthermore,  the previously announced COVID-19 loan scheme will be interest-free for 12 months (prev. 6 months). No business VAT will be paid until June-end. Universal Credit will be increased by GBP 1,000 for the next 12 months; working tax credit also increased by GBP 1,000. The minimum income floor will be suspended so self-employed people can fully access Universal Credit at a rate equivalent to statutory sick pay. Sunak highlighted the GBP 6bln of extra support through the welfare system, as well as close to GBP 1bln of support by increasing the generosity of housing benefit and Universal Credit, so that the Local Housing Allowance will cover at least 30% of market rents. The further, unprecedented fiscal measures saw some selling in GBP after the announcement. The Chancellor said the measures would be funded through regular debt operations; note that the UK DMO is to publish the revised 2020/21 borrowing remit given the coronavirus measures on April 23rd.

LONDON / UK: UK PM Johnson told cafes, pubs, restaurants, gyms, leisure centres, and similar venues to shut from Friday evening, although did not provide specifics on the enforceability of the request (Health Minister Hancock earlier said that if people do not follow advice, then tougher measures may need to be imposed); he also advised restaurants to offer takeout while closed. Johnson said the government does not want to immobilize the tube or other travel networks. Elsewhere, social distancing in the UK could be required for the remainder of the year, according to reports.

EUROPEAN STIMULUS: The German supplementary budget to counter the coronavirus will be significantly above EUR 100bln, according to sources, which could reach EUR 150bln; prior reports via Handelsblatt noted this was to be EUR 100bln in size. Handelsblatt noted that half of the funding will make a fund for small Co's; the package is to be financed completely via debt, as well as being approved on Monday. EU Commissioner Gentolini said discussions on coronabond insurance needs to continue, saying ESM would be the best issuer for this. Furthermore, EU Commission President von der Leyen said coronabond will be used if it helps; the President also said countries must now pump money onto their economies, and the EU is to loosen debt rules, saying it is right time to be flexible and generous. The Swiss government announced a CHF 32bln aid package. Italian PM Conte has called on the EU to utilise the ESM and provide emergency lines of credit to countries, FT reported.

EUROPEAN TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS: French Foreign Minister said France may extend its countrywide lockdown. Italy may extend lockdown to May 1st. Spain ordered the closure of all hotels due to coronavirus, AFP reported.

CHINA: China's Cabinet is to speed up the implementation of phased and targeted tax cuts as well as fee cuts for firms to aid employment.

CASE COUNT – figures provided Friday against previous provided Thursday:

  • CANADA total cases 925 (prev. 873), death toll 12 (prev. 12).
  • CHINA total cases 80,967 (prev. 80,928), death toll 3,248 (prev. 3245).
  • FRANCE total cases 12,612 (prev. 10,995), death toll 450 (prev. 372).
  • GERMANY total cases 19,848 (prev. 13,944), death toll 59 (prev. 44).
  • ITALY total cases 47,021 (prev. 41,035), death toll 4,032 (prev. 3,405).
  • NETHERLANDS total cases 2,994 (prev. 2,460), death toll 106 (prev. 76).
  • SOUTH KOREA total cases 8,652 (prev. 8,565), death toll 94 (prev. 91).
  • SPAIN total cases 19,980 (prev. 17,147), death toll 1,002 (prev. 767).
  • SWITZERLAND 4,849 (prev. 3,888), death toll 56 (prev. 43).
  • UK total cases 3,983 (prev. 3268), death toll 167 (prev. 144).
  • US total cases 15,219 (prev. 10,442), death toll 201 (prev. 150); NY State cases 7,102 (prev. 4,152).

CENTRAL BANKS

SWAP LINES: The Fed, BoE, BoC, BoJ, SNB, and ECB announced coordinated action for further liquidity provision via FX swap lines, moving to daily operations from Monday (prev. weekly). The Fed announced it is to continue through till the end of April at the very least and will continue to hold weekly 84-day maturity operations.

FED has expanded support for municipal and money markets via its MMLF through the Boston Fed, which is now able to lend to financial institutions secured by assets purchased from single state or other tax-exempt money market funds. Elsewhere, the Fed said it is encouraged by the notable rise in Discount Window borrowing this week, which shows banks' willingness to use the, previously stigmatised, facility as a source of funding for household and business credit, while reports noted that banks tapped USD 28.2bln in discount window borrowing this week vs. USD 11mln last week.

NY FED OPERATIONS: NY Fed is to maintain the afternoon daily USD 500bln O/N repo operations for the remainder of the month. Meanwhile, immediate funding pressures seem abated, where take up in the O/N and term operations remains limited. Meanwhile, the Fed purchased USD 122bln of Treasuries and MBS securities on Friday, announcing that it was to make MBS purchases of at least USD 100bln next week and will release a schedule each day for the next day’s operations (purchasing USD 40bln on Monday).

BOE announced supervisory and prudential policy measures due to the coronavirus: suspending 2020 bank stress tests and postponing joint BoE/FCA survey into open-ended funds.

PBOC disappointed those looking for action, in which it skipped liquidity operations again and disappointed calls for a cut to the Prime Loan Rate. It left the PBoC 1-Year Loan Prime Rate (Mar) at 4.05% (exp. 4.00%), with the 5-Year Loan Prime Rate (Mar) at 4.75% (exp. 4.70%). Goldman Sachs’ analysts believe that the PBOC’s loosening has not yet come to an end, citing the absence of loosening measures in China post the Fed rate cut on March 6th, as well as the challenging macro environment and the pressure on banks in terms of the capital and provisions that are needed for.

NORGES: In an emergency announcement the Norges Bank cut rates by 75bp to 0.25% from 1.0%, which is the second emergency rate cut they have taken after a 50bp cut earlier in the week. The move follows on from the Bank remarking they are looking at the FX space and are considering intervening via NOK purchases, as well as the provision of another bout of extraordinary F-loans this week. While the meeting was ‘extraordinary’ the move wasn’t too surprising given recent policy remarks as well as the continued decline in liquidity for the market, with ING remarking the NOK has the lowest liquidity amongst G10 peers. As such, reaction to this release was very minimal, particularly as the Bank is now running out of conventional policy space given previous precedent about the use of other measures such a QE or negative rates.

EQUITIES:

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -4.78% at 2294, NDX -4.04% at 6994, DJIA -4.55% at 19174.

SECTORS: Utilities -8.18%, Cons Stpl -6.53%, Real Estate -5.48%, Industrials -5.04%, Communication Svs -4.63%, Technology -4.42%, Health -4.08%, Materials -3.53%, Financials -3.2%, Cons Disc -2.71%, Energy +0.96%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: US President Trump announced for any companies receiving aid he will demand there be no buybacks. The latest companies to request aid are the car rental services, Avis Budget Corp (CAR) & Hertz (HTZ). While the Airlines for Americas trade association said the industry needs “immediate financial assistance” to protect the 11mln jobs it represents. Those heavily hit earlier in the week amid mass closures and cancellations of operations, MGM Resorts (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Carnival (CCL) among outperforming stocks on Friday as it recoups from the prior losses. While Carnival (CCL) reported preliminary earnings, which saw EPS miss estimates at 0.22/shr with CCL noting the coronavirus resulted in a net loss of USD 0.23/shr to its EPS, although revenue was firmer than expected at USD 4.8bln; NCLH & RCL also saw solid gains. Reports in Nikkei noted Apple’s (AAPL) supply chain woes may not be over even as China starts to recover due to supplier factory closures elsewhere such as Malaysia. Boeing (BA) is reportedly leaning towards a temporary halt at its twin-aisle jetliner factories in a similar move to Airbus (AIR FP), according to people familiar with the matter. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) announced its supply chain is currently holding steady and meeting patient needs. Gilead (GILD) was upgraded at Piper Sandler who were positive on the rewards a successful vaccine against COVID-19 would bring. Tesla’s (TSLA) Fremont, CA factory was ordered to halt production, as was its factory in NY. Coty (COTY) provided an update on the coronavirus noting its activations on Amazon has seen US sales nearly double in recent weeks, as well as noting it is to launch the Kylie skin-care Europe in upcoming weeks; it is also preparing for increased demand post coronavirus. Danaher Corp. (DHR) announced the US FTC is on board with the acquisition of General Electric’s (GE) Life Sciences Biopharma Business and it expects the deal to close on March 31st, 2020. AT&T (T) was hit after it announced its USD 4bln accelerated share repurchase programme has been cancelled, stating the impact of the virus could be material. Crowdstrike (CRWD) surged on solid earnings and guidance, Tiffany’s (TIF) were flat despite top and bottom-line beats, although gross margin was slightly short. Cintas (CTAS) saw solid earnings although gross margin was slightly short, but several broker downgrades weakened the stock citing a cloudy future as it withdraws its guidance for Q4 and FY20.

CRUDE:

SETTLEMENT: WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 3.28 LOWER AT 22.63/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLED USD 1.49 LOWER AT 26.98/BBL.

ANOTHER DAY OF HEAVY PRICE ACTION AMONG THE CRUDE COMPLEX, particularly WTI which seems to be getting particularly volatile as the coronavirus spreads and pushes the economy off the edge. After seeing its largest recorded gain in history on Thursday, WTI has pared back a majority of the bounce and has fallen back towards the USD 20/bbl figure. This week’s Baker Hughes US Rig Count saw drillers cut rigs by 20 to 772, the largest weekly cut since April 2019.

ON THE RUSSIA/SAUDI FRONT, a Russian government spokesperson stated Russia views Saudi’s plan to increase production as blackmail adding it will not back down and “remains ready for contact on prices”, appearing to show no sign of ease of the pricing war, although the Kremlin denies there is a pricing war between the two oil giants. Russia also added that the low oil prices are unpleasant, but not a catastrophe adding it has enough reserves and a sufficient cushion. The Kremlin rebuffed the report on potential US sanctions who were reportedly looking to intervene in the pricing war. However, the latest WSJ reports suggest OPEC is to meet with US shale producers today which could help towards a truce between the world's three largest oil producers, and perhaps resolve the Saudi/Russia pricing war, according to people familiar with the matter which added some support to the benchmarks.

US Energy officials are pushing the Trump administration to forge an oil alliance with Saudi Arabia, which could pave the way for Saudi’s to leave OPEC, according to WSJ sources. Also of note, in fitting with source reports yesterday, officials in Texas have reached out to the Trump administration with consideration of a 10% oil production cut if Russia and Saudi did the same.

BONDS

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 1 POINT 16+ HIGHER AT 136-23+.

THE TPLEX BULL FLATTENED to end the week - 2s10s -10bps to 57.70; 2-year yield 0.356%, 10-year yield 0.94%, 30-year yield 1.58%. The bid was felt throughout the session, coming alongside equities rolling lower. Support was also found amid the Fed’s continued Treasury purchases, filling offers in poor liquidity as many participants are physically absent from their screens. Meanwhile, corporate IG issuance continued, following Thursday’s slew, with Intel and Coke raising USD 8bln and 5bln, respectively, while credit spreads narrowed slightly. Across the pond, the Euro issuance market even had a revival, no doubt the ECB’s latest PEPP package providing some confidence, seeing Engie and Unilever raise EUR 2.5bln and 2bln, respectively.

FOREX:

WEEKLY FX WRAP:

USD/XAU: When push really comes to shove and a crisis spreads through financial markets into credit, the Greenback’s credentials as the ultimate universal currency appear firmly intact. Indeed, the Buck remains on course to secure whopping gains vs all rivals even though the DXY has dipped from best levels just a tick short of 103.000 compared to a low of 97.440, with so called safer havens trailing in wake amidst the scramble for USD liquidity and cash above all else, including other assets. Moreover, Dollar demand has been almost insatiable at times irrespective of risk sentiment and whether US Treasury yields have been rising, falling in bull or bear steepening mode. However, the Fed’s roll out of more swap lines to various Central Bank counterparts on Thursday, and then subsequent enhancement of liquidity provisions to daily ops from weekly has enabled/helped other G10s to claw back some lost ground. The demand for dollars particularly weighed on Gold prices as the precious metal fell beneath 1500/oz as the demand for cash in the current environment took precedence.

GBP/AUD/CAD/NZD: As noted above, Friday’s major standings are far from indicative or tell the full story, as the Pound rebounds from worst levels near 1.1400, but fades circa 1.1930 and still roughly 5 big figures under weekly highs in wake of the BoE slashing rates to the MPC’s stated lower bound (0.1%) and unleashing an additional GBP 200bln APF. Meanwhile, the UK Chancellor has pledged over GBP 300 bn in COVID-19 relief and support with more to be revealed shortly as the Government is poised to impose tighter virus containment restrictions akin to those already being enforced elsewhere. Turning to the non-US Dollars, and it’s a similar pattern of trying to draw lines in the sand after further emergency easing, liquidity injections and the first foray into QE for the RBA. The Aussie is hovering around 0.5850 within a 0.5508-0.6303 range, Loonie circa 1.4360 between 1.3735-1.4667 extremes and Kiwi just under 0.5750 having been down to 0.5472 and as high as 0.6153. The Loonie was relatively unreactive after retail sales data on Friday which rose 0.4% above expectations for 0.3% while the core figure slipped to -0.1%, against expectations for a 0.2% gain, however the data was for January therefore rather stale and before the coronavirus took its toll on global economies.

EUR/CHF/JPY: All ending at new or near existing troughs vs the Usd, as the Euro, Yen and Franc succumb to the aforementioned bullish Greenback forces that have propelled it higher this week. The single currency has been undermined by the rapid spread of nCoV to the point that fatalities in Italy now exceed those in China and the case/death toll climbs across the bloc, with the ECB radically adding to its targeted policy stimulus via a mammoth EUR 750bln PEPP to supplement growing Government fiscal packages including German that is getting closer to shelving its debt brake. Conversely, the SNB has been relatively constrained given ongoing and heightened direct intervention, leaving the Government to tap its budget rather than stretching the balance sheet further, but did raise the stakes in terms of the CHF’s valuation from high to even higher. Meanwhile, the BoJ has resorted to more day-to-day asset purchases, for now, as USDJPY probes above 111.45 vs 105.16 at one stage, USDCHF rests much nearer the top of 0.9890-0.9393 bounds than the trough and EURUSD slips through 1.0700 again towards its 1.0654 base compared to 1.1236 earlier in the week when the Dollar was still adjusting to a 100 bp US rate cut and Usd700 bn QE.

SCANDI/EM: Volatile and largely traumatic weeks doesn’t really touch the surface with regard to the fate of the Norwegian and Swedish Crowns after renewed crude selling to fresh post-Saudi Arabia vs Russia price and market share war outbreak lows, the Norges Bank pulling the benchmark depo rate down to 0.25% and Riksbank opting to buy more bonds rather than reverse December’s repo normalisation to zero and re-join the NIRP club. However, the prospect of intervention and independent Euro weakness has kept EURNOK off 13.1678 record peaks, while EURSEK is back within striking distance of 11.0000 compared to 11.3650 at one stage. In terms of EMs, it’s a case of where does one start and realistically there is too much to report or cover in detail, but essentially intervention and other measures to prevent extreme devaluation bordering on capital flight has been commonplace in the face of monetary easing and fiscal expansion to counter the coronavirus contagion. On that note, the SARB exceeded expectations with a full point rate reduction, but the CBR stood pat as anticipated and resorted to defending the Rouble via direct FX action based on a USD 25/bbl base for Brent.

EMFX: Brazillian Central Bank cut rates by 50bps in a unanimous decision, deeper than the 25bps consensus, while continuing its FX intervention to aid against the steep BRL declines. The announcement saw USDBRL gap up to c. 5.20, however, the BRL appreciated throughout the cross pared-back throughout the tail end of the week and resides just above the 5.00 handle. Banxico the latest to issue an emergency rate cut, where it cut by 50bps to 6.5%, noting it will add liquidity measures to provide liquidity and improve the functioning of financial markets.

subject: Russia's Rosneft says oil could rise to USD 60/bbl by year-end if shale oil leaves the market; says Russia and OPEC should maintain contacts, according to RIA
CFTC FX COT: Specs flip to USD short for the first time since June 2018

• EUR long 32K vs 13K short last week. Longs increased by 45k
  • GBP long 19K vs 26K long last week. Longs decreased by 7K
  • JPY long 33K vs 8K long last week. Longs increased by 25K
  • CHF long 7K vs square last week. Longs increased by 7K
  • AUD short 28k vs 54K short last week. Shorts decreased by 26K
  • NZD short 20K  vs 15K short last week. Shorts increased by 5K
  • CAD short 9k vs 2K short last week. Longs increased by 7K

subject: US President Trump says he is talking about much more than a USD 1,000 check for unemployed Americans

Elsewhere, similar fade in USTs following forecast beating US housing data, but highly unlikely due to the relatively stale numbers that will be more than overshadowed by forthcoming releases revealing COVID-19 repercussions. Meanwhile, the Dollar has bounced from fairly shallow retracement lows as the DXY meanders between 101.070-102.99, but enhanced and more frequent Fed liquidity provisions appear to have clipped the Greenback’s wings.

analysis_details: A choppy open sees initial gains lost with the majority of sectors trading in negative territory with financials, utilities, materials and consumer staples lagging. Financials likely trading of the fall in US yields with the 10-year back around the 1% mark. Note, the Federal Reserve stated it is encouraged by a notable increase in discount window borrowing, which had previously held a stigma around utilizing the rate. Consumer Discretionary (XLY) an outperformer today amid solid gains in MGM (MGM), Wynn (WYNN), Carinval (CCL) and Marriott (MAR) after a week of heavy declines and perhaps on some hope surrounding government aid. More specifically, Sysco (SYY, XLP) performing well amid the announcement it will donate 2.5mln meals over the next four weeks as part of its response strategy to help against COVID-19. Elsewhere it has withdrawn its three-year plan guidance due to the impact from the coronavirus. United Airlines (UAL) firmer after reports suggested Apollo Global Management (APO) has purchased part of the airlines USD 2bln loan from a group of banks. Meanwhile, AT&T (T) lower after it announced it has cancelled its accelerated share repurchase programme of USD 4bln worth of stock, noting the impact of the coronavirus could be material although it cannot currently estimate the impact onto its financial or operational results.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 20th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

20th March 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1300GMT/0900CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

  • Note, California Governor Newsom has ordered its 40mln residents to stay at home excluding essential activities.
  • Of note for Airlines (LUV, DAL, AAL, UAL) (Industrials/Airlines), the Airlines for Americas trade association says the industry needs “immediate financial assistance” to protect the 11mln jobs it represents.
  • Of note for Banks (JPM, C, MS, BAC, GS) (Financials/Diversified Banks), the Fed is encouraged by a notable increase in discount window borrowing as banks show a willingness to use the window as a funding source to support the flow of credit to households and businesses.
  • Of note for Car Rental Services (HTZ, CAR), both Hertz and Avis Budget Corp have requested aid from the US government.

Dow Jones

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) supply chain is reportedly still facing supply disruptions even as China recovers due to factory closures of suppliers in Malaysia. Elsewhere, it has limited the number of purchases on its iPhones to two per customer in the US and China, according to Canalys.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is reportedly leaning towards a temporary halt of operations at its twin-aisle jetliner factories due to the spread of the coronavirus, according to people familiar with the matter, in a similar move to Airbus (AIR FP).
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) Global Supply Chain Officer Wengel announced its supply chain is currently holding steady and meeting patient needs.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) announced it is planning to give special cash bonuses for hourly associates for their work during the current conditions with full-time associates receiving USD 300 and part-time associates receiving USD 150, which will equate to USD 365mln. EMT is to also accelerate its next bonus for store, club and supply chain associates which will equate to USD 180mln, overall it will equate to USD 550mln, the co. says. WMT is to also hire over 150k hourly employees as the number of shoppers increases.

Nasdaq 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) – Some sellers state its decision to stop receiving non-essential inventory in response to the coronavirus pandemic could limit sales they need to make payments on its loans from Amazon.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) announced it decided to temporarily suspend production at its Fremont, California factory and NY Factory after March 23rd. Elsewhere, CEO Musk announced his factories are working on ventilators to address a potential shortage.
  • United Continental Holdings (UAL) (Industrials/Airlines) – Apollo Global Management (APO) has reportedly purchased part of the airlines USD 2bln loan from a group of banks, according to people familiar with the matter.

S&P 500

  • Accenture plc (ACN) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) had its PT cut at a number of brokers, however, they were positive on its ability to continue through the coronavirus crisis.
  • AFLAC Inc (AFL) (Financials/Life & Health Insurance) American Family Life Assurance of Columbus and New York agreed to acquire Zurich North America's US corporate Life and Pensions. AFL expects the acquisition to be dilutive to 2020 adj. EPS by USD 0.02 to 0.03.
  • Altria Group Inc (MO) (Consumer Staples/Tobacco) announced it is temporarily suspending operations at its Richmond manufacturing center.
  • Anthem Inc. (ANTM) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) announced it is offering up to 80 hours of paid emergency leave for qualifying needs, including if associates are experiencing coronavirus symptoms or for caring for young children whose school has been closed.
  • AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) announced it has cancelled is accelerates share repurchase programme of USD 4bln worth of stock, noting the impact of the coronavirus could be material although it cannot currently estimate the impact onto its financial or operational results.
  • Bank of America Corp (BAC) (Financials/Diversified Banks) announced it is offering additional support for its consumer and small business clients in response to the coronavirus, where clients can request funds including overdraft fees, non-sufficient funds fees, and monthly maintenance fees through deposit accounts. Many customers can also request to defer any payments.
  • Carnival Corp. (CCL) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) preliminary Q1 20 (USD): EPS 0.22 (exp. 0.27), revenue 4.8bln (exp. 4.66bln); coronavirus resulted in a net loss of 0.23/shr.
  • Cintas Corporation (CTAS) (Industrials/Diversified Support Services) Q3 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 2.16 (exp. 2.02), revenue 1.81bln (exp. 1.8bln), gross margin 45.5% (exp. 45.7%, prev. 44.9% Y/Y); announced it is not providing guidance for Q4 20 and it is suspending FY20 guidance due to uncertainty surrounding the coronavirus.
  • Coty, Inc (COTY) (Consumer Staples/Personal Products) provided an update on the current situation: Expects Q3 20 revenue to fall approximately 20% like for like, with a meaningful impact on profit, it has also withdrawn FY20 guidance. It is recommending to the board that shareholders be given the option to receive up to 100% of their quarterly dividend in kind for the coming two quarters. Its largest shareholder JAB decided to fully repay the loan it used to finance the tender offer in 2019. It is taking initiatives to manufacture hand sanitizer. Notes activations on Amazon have seen US sales nearly double in recent weeks, as well as launching the Kylie skin-care Europe in upcoming weeks; it is also preparing for increased demand post coronavirus.
  • Danaher Corp. (DHR) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) announced the US FTC is on board with the acquisition of General Electric’s (GE) Life Sciences Biopharma Business. The closing of the deal is still subject to customary closing conditions as announced in the agreement, but DHR expects the deal to close on March 31st, 2020.
  • Ford Motor (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) announced it has plans to suspend production in Argentina and Brazil starting next week due to the coronavirus.
  • Kohl's Corp. (KSS) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) announced it is to close its stores nationwide through to at least April 1st, although customers will still be able to shop on its App. It also withdrew guidance for Q1 and FY20.
  • Mylan N.V. (MYL) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced it is increasing production of its malaria drug for potential use to combat the coronavirus.
  • Occidental Petroleum (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) is reportedly planning on naming its former CEO Stephen Chazen as its new chairman as it tries to improve amid weak demand and activism from Carl Icahn, according to WSJ citing people familiar with the matter.
  • Sysco Corp. (SYY) (Consumer Staples/Food Distributors) announced it will donate 2.5mln meals over the next four weeks as part of its response strategy to help against COVID-19. Elsewhere, it has withdrawn its three-year plan guidance due to the impact from the coronavirus.
  • Tiffany & Co. (TIF) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.80 (exp. 1.77), revenue 1.4bln (exp. 1.36bln); SSS +3%, SSS Ex-Hong Kong +5%, Gross Margin 63.3% (Prev. Y/Y 63.8%). Announced it will not be issuing FY20 guidance due to the pending merger with LVMH (MC FP).

Other

  • Crowdstrike (CRWD) (Information Technology/Software) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS -0.02 (exp. -0.08), Revenue 152mln (exp. 137mln); FY21 Adj. EPS view -0.14 to -0.10 (exp. -0.18), revenue view 723-733mln (exp. 685mln)
  • Samsung (SSNLF) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has reportedly been hit hard by Vietnam’s travel restrictions from South Korea, fueling concerns its Galaxy Note smartphones will fall behind schedule in its largest manufacturing hub outside South Korea, according to Nikkei.
  • Teva (TEVA) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced it will be donating over 6mln doses of hydroxychloroquine sulfate tablets across the US to meet the urgent demand for the medicine as an investigational target to treat the coronavirus.

content:
Schedule pulled from NY Fed website, times given in EDT:

  • 9:40 – 10:00 am: Treasury Coupons 7 to 20 year sector, for around USD 6bln
  • 10:30 – 10:50 am: Treasury Coupons 4.5 to 7 year sector, for around USD 11bln
  • 11:20 – 11:40 am: Treasury Coupons 2.25 to 4.5 year sector, for around USD 17bln
  • 12:10 – 12:30 pm: Treasury Coupons 0 to 2.25 year sector, for around USD 25bln
  • 1:00 – 1:20 pm: Treasury Coupons 20 to 30 year sector, for around USD 9bln
  • 1:50 – 2:10 pm: TIPS 7.5 to 30 year sector, for around USD 7bln

MBS purchases schedule:

9:15 - 9:45 AM: For settlement on March 24, 2020 (T+2). 

  • UMBS 30-year 3.0 securities for around $5.0 billion

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 20th March 2020
content:
• European equities trade higher but off best levels; Nasdaq futures briefly hit limit up
  • US Senate Majority Leader McConnell introduced Senate GOP stimulus plan which includes direct payments of USD 1200 per person
  • DXY tested the 103.00 mark briefly, but has since pulled back to the benefit of G10 counterparts
  • UK Chancellor Sunak is expected to announce ‘unprecedented’ support package on Friday including wage subsidies and tax cuts
  • Looking ahead highlights include Canadian Retail Sales, US Existing Home Sales & Quadruple Witching

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell introduced Senate GOP stimulus plan which includes direct payments of USD 1200 per person, relief for small businesses and workers, as well as fresh healthcare related support. Furthermore, the coronavirus bill provides up to USD 208bln in collateralized loans and loan guarantees to US industries including USD 58bln for airlines, with bipartisan discussions to begin today. (Newswires)

G20 conference call to occur next week, according to German Gov't spokesperson; on the coronavirus. (Newswires)

US and Mexico are reportedly considering a partial border closure, which would likely be implemented from Friday. (Newswires/FT)

A number of ‘Major Banks’ have reportedly stated they intend to continue operations via keeping trading floors open and are confident that, in the event of London being placed into a lockdown, that traders would be designated as key workers. (City AM)

Mainland China reported 39 additional cases of coronavirus and 3 additional deaths on March 19th vs. Prev. 34 additional cases and 8 additional deaths on March 18th, which brings the total cases in mainland China to 80967 and death toll at 3248. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 84 additional coronavirus cases for a total of 8652 and death toll increased by 3 to a total 94, while the number of cured increased by 286 to a total of 2233. (Yonhap) Taiwan has accused the WHO of ignoring a warning from Taiwan in December on the risk of human-to-human transmission of the virus, accusing them of slowing the response globally. (FT)

Spain COVID-19 cases rises to 19,980 (prev. 17,147); Switzerland COVID-19 cases rises to 4849; deaths rise to 43. (Newswires)

French Foreign Minister says France may extend its countrywide lockdown. Italy may extend lockdown to May 1st, according to local press. (Newswires) Italian PM Conte has called on the EU to utilise the ESM and provide emergency lines of credit to countries. (FT) Spain ordered the closure of all hotels due to coronavirus. (AFP) UK Health Minister Hancock says if people do not follow advice, then tougher measures may need to be imposed. (Newswires)

German Government intend to set up a rescue package of EUR 500bln for companies and banks due to the coronavirus, according to Der Spiegel. (Der Spiegel) German Labour Institute expects unemployment +90k to 2.356mln in 2020 if the coronavirus is mild, severe case sees it exceeding 3mln; expects GDP decline of 2% if activity stops for 6-weeks before resuming within another 6-weeks. (Newswires)

EU Commissioner Gentolini says discussions on coronabond insurance needs to continue, ESM would be the best issuer for this. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia suspended all domestic flights, buses, taxis and trains for 14 days. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded higher as the region took its cue from the mild rebound on Wall St amid continued policy efforts to contain the coronavirus fallout including the latest 15bps emergency cut by the BoE and with the US Senate working on a deal which would provide USD 1200 cash payment to individuals. ASX 200 (+0.7%) was underpinned by supportive measures including the RBA’s first ever QE operation and the Australian Banking Association announcement that banks will defer loan payments for 6 months on small businesses impacted by the outbreak, while real estate led the gains as the sector found restitution from its recent collapse after the big 4 banks lowered business and home loan rates. KOSPI (+7.4%) outperformed and triggered a side-car as it atoned for the prior day’s substantial losses and related stoppages, while Hang Seng (+5.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.6%) conformed to the rebound after China’s coronavirus epicentre of Hubei reported no new cases for a 2nd consecutive day, but with gains in the mainland restricted by continued PBoC inaction in which it skipped liquidity operations again and disappointed calls for a cut to the Prime Loan Rate. As a reminder, Japanese markets remained closed for Vernal Equinox holiday.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.1052 vs. Exp. 7.1005 (Prev. 7.0522)

PBoC 1-Year Loan Prime Rate (Mar) 4.05% vs. Exp. 4.00% (Prev. 4.05%). (Newswires) PBoC 5-Year Loan Prime Rate (Mar) 4.75% vs. Exp. 4.70% (Prev. 4.75%)

PBoC Adviser Ma states that he sees room for more RRR cuts in China, adds that it takes time for RRR cut to pass to LPR. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU Commission President von der Leyen says countries must now pump money onto their economies, are to loosen debt rules, it is right time to be flexible and generous. On coronabonds: will be used if they will help

UK Chancellor Sunak is expected to announce ‘unprecedented’ support package on Friday including wage subsidies and tax cuts, in addition to the already announced GBP 20bln support and GBP 330bln loan guarantee scheme. Measures under discussion reportedly include freezing income tax and providing national insurance tax breaks. (FT/Telegraph)

BoE announce supervisory and prudential policy measures due to the coronavirus: suspending 2020 bank stress tests, postponing joint BoE/FCA survey into open ended funds. (Newswires) UK DMO are to publish revised 2020/21 borrowing remit given the coronavirus measures on April 23rd. (Newswires)

Norges Bank cut rates to 0.25% from 1.0% in an emergency move; unanimous decision - do not rule out further rate cuts. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European bourses opened with gains of around 5%, and subsequently extended on this given a grinding bid in futures as we entered early EU hours; albeit, indices are just off of highs at present. The region remains underpinned by remarks from EU Commission President von der Leyen which received a wider airing – noting the EU is to loosen debt rules, while specific details were not provided this does follow reports out of Germany yesterday that they wish to apply an exemption to the debt brake, while the debt comments from the European Commission are likely in reference to Growth & Stability Pact deficit limits. Following the EU cash open sentiment continued to improve, to the extent that the Nasdaq March’20 future briefly touched the 5% limit-up level at 7649; with the E-mini S&P and DJIA not far from their respective levels (circuit breakers/limit down levels are listed on the Newsquawk headline feed). Sector performance sees all sectors firmly in the green, with some notable outperformance seen in Energy (+7.0%) as the broader crude complex has rebounded significantly after yesterday's sell-off. In terms of individual movers, Osram Lich (+23%) is by some measure the stand-out after AMS confirmed they are to close on their acquisition in Q2. Other movers are largely moving in-line with sector/bourse performance, with a number of the Stoxx 600 laggards arising from the FTSE 100 which has been weighed on by Sterling's substantial resurgence this morning; ahead of measures from Chancellor Sunak.

FX

USD - Consolidation and corrective trade in the currency markets after the DXY surged to new peaks a fraction shy of 103.000, with the index back below 102.000 amidst a broad recovery in G10 counterparts and EM rivals that are also getting a reprieve from a relief rally in related commodities. However, the Greenback remains bid in volatile conditions ahead of the weekend as the coronavirus vigil continues and global Central Banks join forces with Governments in emergency and/or unprecedented policy action to combat the adverse effects of the pandemic.

AUD/NZD/NOK/GBP/CAD - All leading the comeback from multi-year lows, with the Aussie reclaiming 0.5900+ status and Kiwi more stable above 0.5800, while the Norwegian Crown is outperforming its Swedish peer on the firmer rebound in oil rather than another impromptu Norges Bank rate cut (-75 bp) and more liquidity measures. Similarly, Sterling has not suffered a severe hangover following yesterday’s BoE salvo, as Cable holds well above worst levels within a massive 1.1414-1.1877 range awaiting UK Chancellor Sunak’s supplementary fiscal support package that may be unveiled around noon, while the Loonie is nursing more losses between 1.4151-1.4536 parameters ahead of Canadian retail sales data.

JPY/CHF/EUR - Also attempting to regroup, but hampered somewhat by the latest upturn in risk appetite plus holiday impacted Japanese participation due to Vernal Equinox Day. Nevertheless, Usd/Jpy has retreated from 111.00+ to sub-110.00, Usd/Chf towards 0.9800 vs almost 0.9900 at one stage and even Eur/Usd has managed to clamber back over 1.0700 from almost 1.0650.

EM - Regional currencies are all benefiting from the aforementioned improvement in sentiment or less COVID-19 angst for the time being, but the Rouble is underperforming after the CBR held rates as expected to leave the focus on the tug-of-war over crude prices and market share with Saudi Arabia that Russia has attempted to play down.

Russian Federation Central Bank Key Rate (Mar) 6.00% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. 6.0%); announcing additional temporary measures given virus and low oil prices

Russian Kremlin says the rouble weakness in recent days is a result of a perfect market storm, rebuffs the US media report on potential US sanctions; low prices are unpleasant but not a catastrophe have enough reserves and a sufficient cushion

FIXED INCOME

Gilts are off best levels (133.68 Liffe high) in advance of another UK fiscal rescue package from Chancellor Sunak, but still outperforming and redressing some of the balance that was skewed significantly against them, and Short Sterling contracts yesterday (along with the Pound). Fears over the spread and contagion from nCoV more than the MPC’s latest shock policy stimulus seem to weigh heavily over domestic markets/assets, but the pressure has alleviated somewhat amidst a general revival in bond and rate markets that is keeping Bunds afloat near 170.00 and US Treasuries on the 136-00 handle.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures extend on yesterday’s rally, which saw prices climb over 20% as the complex was buoyed by signals that US President Trump could intervene in the Saudi/Russia price war at “an appropriate time”, with reports of potential sanctions on Russia in a bid to stabilise markets. The benchmarks also experience an underlying bid from reports that the US DoE is planning on stockpiling crude for the SPR. Overall risk appetite also aids the complex in grinding higher after the European Commission President stated that the Union is to loosen debt brakes. WTI May’20 has reclaimed USD 28/bbl to the upside whilst its Brent counterpart gain ground above USD 30.50/bbl, with technicals futile at this stage, meanwhile the spread also widens vs. earlier in the week. Elsewhere, gold prices stage a rebound as DXY loses impetus from its recent rally, and as liquidity concerns somewhat fades for the time being amid a string of Fed liquidity announcements. The yellow metal reclaims a USD +1500/oz status having printed a recent trough just above USD 1450/oz. Finally, the overall sentiment bolsters the red metal back north of USD 2/lb, having briefly lost the handle during the prior session.

CME raised crude oil NYMEX futures margins by 20.4% to USD 5600/contract from USD 4650/contract and is reportedly changing its dynamic circuit breakers for oil to 15% from 7%. Furthermore, CME raised COMEX 5000 silver futures maintenance margins by 14.3% to USD 8000/contract, raised Palladium futures NYMEX initial margins by 9.3% to USD 38500/contract and raised Platinum futures NYMEX margins for specs by 11.1% to USD 4400/contract. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs sees restraint by core-OPEC could raise Brent to USD 30/bbl from its forecast of USD 20/bbl in Q2, while it added that production quotas could result in USD 5-10/bbl upside to its 2021 price forecast of USD 40-50/bbl. (Newswires)

China March apparent refined oil consumption is forecast to decline 19.1% Y/Y. (Newswires)

US

Fed said it is encouraged by notable rise in discount window borrowing this week which shows banks' willingness to use Fed as a source of funding for household and business credit, while reports noted that banks tapped USD 28.2bln in discount window borrowing this week vs. USD 11mln last week. Similarly, Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said it is encouraging to see there is more borrowing at the discount window and that some volatility

has settled down, while she added that tools are beginning to work and will continue to monitor to see if further action is needed. (Newswires)

New York Fed said it will purchase USD 32bln in mortgage-backed securities on Friday and it stands ready to purchase securities as needed for smooth market functioning. (Newswires)

US President Trump reportedly asked states to delay releasing jobless claims data. (NYT)

subject: Bunds: firm start to Friday’s session, but far too soon to say sustainable
content: After an initial Eurex mark-up and minor dip to 168.52 vs Thursday’s 167.94 close it’s been one-way traffic for the 10 year German benchmark as global bonds breathe a huge sigh of relief following the extended and potentially overdone sell-off seen this week. At the very least, consolidation and short covering has lifted debt futures further from the depths, and for Bunds a fresh 167.52 contract low at one stage yesterday when the corresponding cash yield breached -15 bp to the upside. However, it remains to be seen whether the current whether the broad comeback lasts as the core Eurozone bond has faded after a brief foray above 170.00 awaiting further direction.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
20th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA 

Asian equity markets traded higher as the region took its cue from the mild rebound on Wall St amid continued policy efforts to contain the coronavirus fallout including the latest 15bps emergency cut by the BoE and with the US Senate working on a deal which would provide USD 1200 cash payment to individuals. ASX 200 (+0.7%) was underpinned by supportive measures including the RBA’s first ever QE operation and the Australian Banking Association announcement that banks will defer loan payments for 6 months on small businesses impacted by the outbreak, while real estate led the gains as the sector found restitution from its recent collapse after the big 4 banks lowered business and home loan rates. KOSPI (+5.5%) outperformed and triggered a side-car as it atoned for the prior day’s substantial losses and related stoppages, while Hang Seng (+2.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) conformed to the rebound after China’s coronavirus epicentre of Hubei reported no new cases for a 2nd consecutive day, but with gains in the mainland restricted by continued PBoC inaction in which it skipped liquidity operations again and disappointed calls for a cut to the Prime Loan Rate. As a reminder, Japanese markets remained closed for Vernal Equinox holiday

FTSE 100

Supermarkets – UK supermarkets are to apply new rules and restrictions on grocery purchases. (Newswires) Separately, the UK government is temporarily relaxing competition regulations to allow retailers to work together to provide food during the virus outbreak. (Guardian)

Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 20th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Somewhat choppy APAC sentiment, but the tone has improved heading into the EU open
  • DXY tested the 103.00 mark briefly, but has since pulled back to the benefit of G10 counterparts
  • US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose to 10442 (Prev. 7038) and death toll rose to 150; California Governor issued a stay-at-home order
  • US President Trump said at an appropriate time he will get involved in the oil market dispute; Officials are reportedly looking at sanctioning Russia
  • UK Chancellor Sunak is expected to announce ‘unprecedented’ support package on Friday including wage subsidies and tax cuts
  • Looking ahead highlights include German Producer Prices, Canadian Retail Sales, US Existing Home Sales & Quadruple Witching

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Italy COVID-19 total cases rose to 41035 (Prev. 35713) and death toll increased to 3405 to (Prev. 2978). (Newswires) Italian PM Conte has called on the EU to utilise the ESM and provide emergency lines of credit to countries. (FT)

Mainland China reported 39 additional cases of coronavirus and 3 additional deaths on March 19th vs. Prev. 34 additional cases and 8 additional deaths on March 18th, which brings the total cases in mainland China to 80967 and death toll at 3248. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 84 additional coronavirus cases for a total of 8652 and death toll increased by 3 to a total 94, while the number of cured increased by 286 to a total of 2233. (Yonhap)

Taiwan has accused the WHO of ignoring a warning from Taiwan in December on the risk of human-to-human transmission of the virus, accusing them of slowing the response globally. (FT)

US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose to 10442 (Prev. 7038) and death toll rose to 150 (Prev. 97). (Newswires)

US President Trump is said to be okay with a conditional coronavirus bailout banning stock buybacks for companies that receive federal relief, which is a shift in tone from his deputies have defended share repurchases in the past, according to Axios. (Twitter)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell introduced Senate GOP stimulus plan which includes direct payments of USD 1200 per person, relief for small businesses and workers, as well as fresh healthcare related support. Furthermore, the coronavirus bill provides up to USD 208bln in collateralized loans and loan guarantees to US industries including USD 58bln for airlines, with bipartisan discussions to begin today. (Newswires)

US State Department raised Global Health advisory to Level 4 in which it advised US citizens to avoid all international travel due to the coronavirus, while the California Governor issued a state-wide stay at home order. (Newswires)

US and Mexico are reportedly considering a partial border closure, which would likely be implemented from Friday. (Newswires/FT)

A number of ‘Major Banks’ have reportedly stated they intend to continue operations via keeping trading floors open and are confident that, in the event of London being placed into a lockdown, that traders would be designated as key workers. (City AM)

Saudi Arabia suspended all domestic flights, buses, taxis and trains for 14 days. (Newswires)

Spain ordered the closure of all hotels due to coronavirus. (AFP)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded higher as the region took its cue from the mild rebound on Wall St amid continued policy efforts to contain the coronavirus fallout including the latest 15bps emergency cut by the BoE and with the US Senate working on a deal which would provide USD 1200 cash payment to individuals. ASX 200 (+0.7%) was underpinned by supportive measures including the RBA’s first ever QE operation and the Australian Banking Association announcement that banks will defer loan payments for 6 months on small businesses impacted by the outbreak, while real estate led the gains as the sector found restitution from its recent collapse after the big 4 banks lowered business and home loan rates. KOSPI (+5.5%) outperformed and triggered a side-car as it atoned for the prior day’s substantial losses and related stoppages, while Hang Seng (+2.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) conformed to the rebound after China’s coronavirus epicentre of Hubei reported no new cases for a 2nd consecutive day, but with gains in the mainland restricted by continued PBoC inaction in which it skipped liquidity operations again and disappointed calls for a cut to the Prime Loan Rate. As a reminder, Japanese markets remained closed for Vernal Equinox holiday.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.1052 vs. Exp. 7.1005 (Prev. 7.0522)

PBoC 1-Year Loan Prime Rate (Mar) 4.05% vs. Exp. 4.00% (Prev. 4.05%). (Newswires) PBoC 5-Year Loan Prime Rate (Mar) 4.75% vs. Exp. 4.70% (Prev. 4.75%)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak is expected to announce ‘unprecedented’ support package on Friday including wage subsidies and tax cuts, in addition to the already announced GBP 20bln support and GBP 330bln loan guarantee scheme. Measures under discussion reportedly include freezing income tax and providing national insurance tax breaks. (FT/Telegraph)

BoE Governor Bailey said bank has scope to move further if required and that the time to act was now, while he rejected criticism that the move was monetary financing. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson and Irish PM Varadkar spoke regarding coronavirus and agreed to align actions as much as possible, while the leaders also agreed on close cooperation of countries' common travel. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the rally in the USD finally lost steam after having surged to a 3-year high and briefly approached just of the 103.00 level which had been spurred by the rush for cash. Nonetheless, the greenback has since pulled back amid further disruptions including California announcing a state-wide stay at home order, with the retracement providing some much needed reprieve for its major counterparts including EUR/USD which briefly dipped below the 1.0700 handle in the aftermath of the ECB’s PEPP announcement and alongside the ongoing lockdowns across the bloc. GBP/USD continued its recovery from beneath 1.1500 following the fluctuations seen after the BoE’s emergency 15bps cut and APP boost, with focus turning to Chancellor Sunak’s announcement of further support measures later today. Elsewhere, USD/JPY retreated below 111.00 to breach support at 110.00 amid the pullback in USD and with Japanese participants on holiday, while antipodeans benefitted overnight amid a rebound in commodities and improved risk appetite but with gains capped in AUD/USD and NZD/USD by resistance at 0.5900 and 0.5800 respectively, as well as the weakest reference rate setting by the PBoC since 2008. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures extended on the prior day’s 24% gains which was the largest on record after supportive comments stateside including Treasury Secretary Mnuchin who suggested to buy USD 10-20bln worth of oil at low prices and after the DoE formally requested to buy up to 30mln bbls. Furthermore, US President Trump suggested that he will get involved in the oil dispute at an appropriate time and the rebound in stocks helped sustain the upside momentum for crude prices. Elsewhere, gold benefitted as the greenback pulled back from 3-year highs but with upside limited by the improved risk appetite, while copper lagged its peers after prices recently slipped to beneath USD 2.00/lb which was its lowest in 4 years.

US President Trump said at an appropriate time he will get involved in the oil market dispute, while a separate source report suggested US officials are looking at intervening in the Russia-Saudi dispute and possibility of imposing sanctions on the Russians. (Newswires/WSJ)

Texas is mulling curtailing oil output for the first time in decades, according to sources. (WSJ)

CME raised crude oil NYMEX futures margins by 20.4% to USD 5600/contract from USD 4650/contract and is reportedly changing its dynamic circuit breakers for oil to 15% from 7%. Furthermore, CME raised COMEX 5000 silver futures maintenance margins by 14.3% to USD 8000/contract, raised Palladium futures NYMEX initial margins by 9.3% to USD 38500/contract and raised Platinum futures NYMEX margins for specs by 11.1% to USD 4400/contract. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs sees restraint by core-OPEC could raise Brent to USD 30/bbl from its forecast of USD 20/bbl in Q2, while it added that production quotas could result in USD 5-10/bbl upside to its 2021 price forecast of USD 40-50/bbl. (Newswires)

China March apparent refined oil consumption is forecast to decline 19.1% Y/Y. (Newswires)

US

The TPLEX bull steepened after a recent acute sell-off in duration, alongside a bounce in equities. Desks note the improved risk sentiment and incoming fiscal and monetary stimulus has likely put a pause in forced liquidations in DM bonds. Furthermore, the Fed has been ramping up its Treasury purchases – with USD 100bln scheduled for purchase across Thursday and Friday. A large deluge of IG corporate supply didn’t buck the trend either after recent dry spells. By settlement, 10s -0.11bps at 1.147%, 2s -0.08bps at 0.448%, leaving the 2s10s at 69.20.

Fed said it is encouraged by notable rise in discount window borrowing this week which shows banks' willingness to use Fed as a source of funding for household and business credit, while reports noted that banks tapped USD 28.2bln in discount window borrowing this week vs. USD 11mln last week. (Newswires)

Similarly, Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said it is encouraging to see there is more borrowing at the discount window and that some volatility has settled down, while she added that tools are beginning to work and will continue to monitor to see if further action is needed. (Newswires)

New York Fed said it will purchase USD 32bln in mortgage-backed securities on Friday and it stands ready to purchase securities as needed for smooth market functioning. (Newswires)

US President Trump reportedly ask states to delay releasing jobless claims data. (NYT)

New York Stock Exchange President Cunningham said officials have no plans to close the market and are not talking about shortening trading day. (Fox News)

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE STOCK NEWS: Taiwan central bank lowered rates by 25bps vs. Exp. 12.5bps cut
content:
TAIWAN

Other News Taiwan Central Bank cut the benchmark interest rate by 25bps to 1.125% vs. Expected 12.5bps cut to 1.25%. Taiwan Central Bank Governor Yang said monetary policy will be loose from now on and stated that rate decision must be faster and braver. (Newswires)

Taiwan’s FSC banned short-selling in an attempt to curb speculative trading. (Taipei Times)

Taiwan may allow delay on loan repayments amid the coronavirus. (Newswires)

 

SINGAPORE

Other News - Monetary Authority of Singapore established a USD 60bln swap facility which will last 6 month and will provide US dollar liquidity to financial institutions in Singapore. (Straits Times)
